member.name: T:FM.WebSync.Silverlight.Core.ClientInputArgs`3
member.summary: Base input arguments for WebSync methods.

summary.para: Base class that defines the properties and methods shared by any class that is considered extensible by the Bayeux specification.

The Bayeux specification defines the Ext field, which allows custom data to be stored with a message using a namespaced key to access the information. This class provides methods that store and retrieve JSON data stored in this manner. For example, the property uses the Ext field to store its value using "fm.meta" as a key.

In addition, classes which inherit from can store dynamic property values for local read/write access without the need to serialize to JSON. This can aid greatly in the development of third-party extensions to WebSync. Custom information can be stored with method arguments in the "before" event and read out again for further processing in the "after" event.

member.summary: Gets or sets the callback to invoke if the streaming connection fails. See for callback argument details.

remarks.para: This method will be invoked if (a) the connection was lost, automatic retries succeeded, but the client had idled on the server (and so needs to reconnect), or (b) the connection was lost and automatic retries failed. In the former case, is true, and in the latter case, is false.
See for more details on these two scenarios.

If is true, the client will automatically reconnect. If the reconnect succeeds, the callback specified by will be invoked with set to true. If the reconnect fails, the callback specified by will be invoked with set to false.
With the exception of UI updates, invocations of this callback with set to true can be ignored.

member.name: P:FM.WebSync.Silverlight.Core.ConnectArgs.OnUnhandledReceive
member.summary: Gets or sets the callback to invoke when a message is received on a channel that has no local callback specified to handle it. See for callback argument details.
member.remarks: This can occur if (a) a client is manually subscribed to a channel by the server or (b) a client subscribed to a channel and then manually removed the local callback.

member.name: P:FM.WebSync.Silverlight.Core.ConnectArgs.StayConnected
member.summary: Gets or sets whether to always attempt to stay connected in the event of network failure. If true, the client will continually reconnect, even after exhausting the specified number of . If false, the client will stop reconnecting if all retry attempts fail.

member.name: P:FM.WebSync.Silverlight.Core.ConnectArgs.Reconnect
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not the connect is occurring because the connection has been lost and needs to be re-negotiated.

summary.para: The WebSync client, used for subscribing to channels and receiving data, as well as publishing data to specific channels.

remarks.para: If subscribing is not necessary and publishing data is all that is required, use the , which does not maintain a streaming connection to the server for receiving data on subscribed channels.
When using WebSync Server, set the . When using WebSync On-Demand, set the to your public API key and the to your domain.
The WebSync client has 7 primary operations:

list.item: Connect/Disconnect: Responsible for setting up or taking down a streaming connection to the server.
Bind/Unbind: Responsible for attaching and detaching public/private client details like a user name or email address.
Subscribe/Unsubscribe: Responsible for opting in or out of receiving data published to specific channels.
Publish: Responsible for sending data to the server for distribution to clients subscribed to a specific channel.

remarks.para: Each method (and the constructor) take a single "args" object. This object defines callback functions, configuration settings, and error handling information. It allows the client to default to sensible values, while allowing easy overrides.

The WebSync client is designed to be as robust and fault-tolerant as possible. If a network failure occurs while a request is being processed, the client will automatically launch a new attempt. How many times it will retry is based on the specified number of .
Maintaining a streaming connection lies at the heart of WebSync, and so special care is given to ensure that a streaming connection remains active, even in the presence of total network failure.

Since WebSync clients often subscribe to channels to receive partial updates, it is highly recommended to do initial state load in the callback specified by . This way, (a) there are no missed partial updates between the state load and the subscription, and (b) in the event of connection failure and automatic reconnection/resubscription, the state will be automatically refreshed.
There are two possible scenarios for streaming connection failures.
remarks.h5: Scenario 1: Connection lost, automatic retries succeed, but the client has idled on the server
remarks.para: In this scenario, the client will be returned to its former state automatically - the connection will be re-established and any bindings and subscriptions will be automatically restored. However, because the server considered the client to be idle, it was automatically disconnected and unsubscribed, meaning any data sent to it's subscribed channel(s) during that time will not be received.
How to handle: update the UI to indicate temporary disconnection.

list.item: The callback specified by will always be invoked first with the flag set to true. UI updates to indicate disconnection should occur here.

The client will then proceed to aquire a new client ID automatically using the last set of arguments passed in. If the reconnection succeeds, the callback specified by will be invoked with the flag set to true. Otherwise, the callback specified by will be invoked with the flag set to true.

Next, any client bindings will be restored automatically. If a rebind succeeds, the callback specified by will be invoked with the flag set to true. Otherwise, the callback specified by will be invoked with the flag set to true.

Finally, any client subscriptions will be restored automatically. If a resubscribe succeeds, the callback specified by will be invoked with the flag set to true. Otherwise, the callback specified by will be invoked with the flag set to true.

remarks.h5: Scenario 2: Connection lost, automatic retries fail.
remarks.para: If the network connection could not be re-established using the number of retries available, the client must give up. This can be avoided by setting the number of to a higher number or by setting to true, which will force the client to repeat its attempts even if the number of retries is exhausted.
How to handle: update the UI to incidate permanent disconnection.

list.item: The callback specified by will be invoked with the flag set to false. UI updates to indicate disconnection should occur here.

example.para: Here's a simple example of how to create a client in C#, establish a streaming connection, start listening for data, and publish a message to other subscribers. (Launch two copies to see the message delivery.)
For those uncomfortable with the lambda-style creation of methods, this can easily be written in the old style of C# as well. Here's just a partial sample:

member.summary: Sets a callback to be invoked whenever messages are received for the specified channel. This will override any previous callbacks linked to the channel.

remarks.para: This method does not subscribe you to a channel. Rather, it caches a callback to be executed when messages are received on a particular channel. This is typically done in parallel with a server-side subscribe (not requested by the client) to set a local callback in the cache.
This overrides any previous callback set for the specified channel.

member.param: The channel over which the messages will be received.

member.name: M:FM.WebSync.Silverlight.Core.Client.Connect
member.summary: Sets up and maintains a streaming connection to the server using default values.
member.remarks: While this method will typically run asychronously, the WebSync client is designed to be used without (much) consideration for its asynchronous nature. To that end, any calls to methods that require an active connection, like bind, subscribe, and publish, will be queued automatically and executed once this method has completed successfully.

summary.para: The WebSync publisher, used for publishing data rapidly and efficiently.

remarks.para: When developing real-time applications, it is often most efficient and secure to publish data from a server, a web service, or in general, a source that doesn't require the ability to subscribe to channels. The is designed to do just that.
When using WebSync Server, set the . When using WebSync On-Demand, set the to your public API key and the to your domain.

A common use case for the is to send out data as it arrives from a real-time feed (e.g. stock data, sports scores, news articles, etc.). Wherever the feed is located, the can be used to send out the data rapidly to any subscribed clients.
For WebSync Server, make sure httpDirectPublish is enabled in web.config.

example.para: Here's a simple example of how to create a publisher in C# and publish some data.

remarks.para: There are multiple overloads for the "Publish" method. For batch publications, use the overloads that take a collection of Publications. They will be automatically batched and delivered in a single round-trip.
